9a.question: A 54-year-old male with a history of GERD presents with upper abdominal pain radiating to the back. On exam, there is a warm, boggy spasm at T6 on the left. Which of the following statements is most accurate?
options: A. The T6 segment indicates a viscerosomatic reflex from the stomach.
B. The finding suggests a facilitated segment due to cardiac issues.
C. T6 involvement rules out any gastrointestinal causes.
D. The T6 lesion must be treated with HVLA before any other techniques.
E. This presentation is most consistent with musculoskeletal strain.

9a.question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the role of the diaphragm in lymphatic drainage?
options: A. It has no effect on the lymphatic system.
B. Dysfunction of the diaphragm can impede lymphatic flow and contribute to edema.
C. The diaphragm enhances sympathetic nerve activity.
D. Lymphatic drainage is independent of diaphragmatic motion.
E. The diaphragm only affects venous drainage, not lymphatic.

9a.question: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is being evaluated. Which osteopathic consideration is most relevant in enhancing their respiratory efficiency?
options: A. Correcting upper thoracic type II dysfunctions.
B. Treating the diaphragm and ribcage to improve respiratory-circulatory function.
C. Reducing sympathetic tone at T10-T12.
D. Focusing solely on lumbar spine adjustments.
E. Using counterstrain on the lower extremity muscles.

9a.question: What is the most appropriate osteopathic treatment strategy for a 70-year-old patient with osteoporosis and a recent vertebral compression fracture at T8?
options: A. Employing HVLA on T8 to restore motion.
B. Using gentle counterstrain and myofascial release techniques to manage pain and improve mobility.
C. Prescribing only pharmacological treatment without osteopathic manipulative treatment.
D. Ignoring the thoracic spine and treating only the lumbar region.
E. Applying muscle energy to induce high-stress adjustments.

9a.question: Which statement best describes the concept of segmental facilitation?
options: A. It refers to the inability of spinal segments to respond to autonomic input.
B. It is a chronic condition where viscerosomatic reflexes amplify somatic dysfunction, leading to heightened and persistent spinal sensitivity.
C. It results in immediate resolution of pain upon the initiation of counterstrain.
D. Segmental facilitation is unrelated to any changes in autonomic function.
E. It is a phenomenon exclusively associated with cranial manipulation.

9a.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with left-sided chest pain and palpatory findings of a warm, boggy spasm at T3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
options: A. A musculoskeletal injury involving the thoracic spine.
B. A viscerosomatic reflex due to cardiac involvement.
C. A chronic type I dysfunction at T3.
D. An acute type II dysfunction at T7 on the left.
E. A herniated thoracic disc at T3.

9a.question: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of a Type II somatic dysfunction?
options: A. It occurs in a neutral spine and is maintained by long restrictor muscles.
B. It involves rotation and sidebending to the same side, maintained by short restrictor muscles.
C. It presents as a group curve affecting multiple segments.
D. It only occurs during flexion of the spine.
E. It does not involve any rotation or sidebending.

9a.question: A 45-year-old patient with chronic low back pain is diagnosed with a Type I dysfunction in the lumbar region. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial osteopathic approach?
options: A. Use high-velocity, low-amplitude (HVLA) on the dysfunctional lumbar segments.
B. Address and treat any associated Type II dysfunctions before correcting the Type I group curve.
C. Apply counterstrain directly to the iliopsoas muscle.
D. Ignore the lumbar spine and focus on the thoracic region.
E. Only use passive range of motion exercises without osteopathic manipulation.

9a.question: Which statement is most accurate regarding the presentation of a thoracic herniated disc?
options: A. It commonly presents with significant lower extremity weakness.
B. It rarely refers pain to the chest wall or abdominal area.
C. It is less common than lumbar disc herniation but may cause serious neurological symptoms.
D. It presents with a sharp pain limited to the lumbar region.
E. It does not cause any sensory disturbances in dermatomal patterns.

9a.question: A patient presents with thoracic kyphosis and reports progressive upper back pain. The curvature is measured at 80 degrees with tenderness over the apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Postural kyphosis.
B. Scheuermann’s disease.
C. Type I somatic dysfunction.
D. Scoliosis with rotational component.
E. Simple muscle strain.

9a.question: A 75-year-old patient with a history of osteoporosis presents with mid-back pain. Imaging shows a compression fracture at T10. Based on the respiratory-circulatory model, which treatment would be most appropriate?
options: A. High-velocity, low-amplitude (HVLA) at T10 to restore mobility.
B. Myofascial release of the thoracic cage to improve diaphragm function and circulation.
C. Rib raising to decrease sympathetic tone at T1-T4.
D. Muscle energy targeting the lumbar spine to stabilize the thoracic area.
E. Counterstrain focusing on the lower cervical region.

9a.question: A 62-year-old female presents with upper abdominal discomfort and bloating. She has tenderness and tissue texture changes at T5-T9 on the left side. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
options: A. Type I somatic dysfunction due to poor posture.
B. Viscerosomatic reflex associated with the stomach.
C. Segmental facilitation affecting the liver.
D. Muscular spasm unrelated to visceral organs.
E. Lumbar spine dysfunction radiating to the thoracic area.

9a.question: Which of the following best describes the role of the thoracic inlet in lymphatic drainage?
options: A. It acts as the primary pump for lymphatic circulation.
B. Obstruction here can impede lymphatic drainage throughout the body.
C. It only affects lymphatic flow to the upper extremities.
D. Its role is limited to facilitating venous drainage.
E. It has no significant effect on lymphatic function.

9a.question: A patient with COPD presents with restricted chest expansion and thoracic kyphosis. Which osteopathic treatment goal aligns with the biomechanical model in this case?
options: A. Improving diaphragm mobility and reducing thoracic stiffness.
B. Increasing venous return to the thoracic inlet.
C. Reducing sympathetic tone in the upper thoracic region.
D. Enhancing lymphatic drainage at the thoracic outlet.
E. Encouraging lumbar spine flexibility.

9a.question: A 48-year-old male complains of left-sided abdominal pain after meals. Physical exam reveals vertebral rotation with boggy tissue texture at T10-T11 on the left. This finding most likely indicates:
options: A. A facilitated segment related to the kidneys.
B. Somatic dysfunction due to poor posture.
C. A viscerosomatic reflex from the lower gastrointestinal tract.
D. Type I dysfunction affecting a group of vertebrae.
E. Segmental facilitation related to a musculoskeletal injury.

9b.question: Which of the following best describes the parasympathetic innervation of the lower GI tract?
options: A. CN III, VII, IX, X up to the splenic flexure
B. S2-S4 to the remaining GI and pelvic viscera
C. T5-T9 via the celiac plexus
D. T10-T12 for the descending colon
E. CN IX for the entire GI tract

9b.question: Which of the following is a sign of acute somatic dysfunction?
options: A. Firm, ropy muscles upon palpation
B. Rapid fading of redness during an erythema test
C. Warm, moist skin with a positive erythema test
D. Cool, dry skin with pigment changes
E. Fibrotic texture in the affected area

9b.question: What is the primary effect of sympathetic stimulation on the heart?
options: A. Decreased heart rate and contractility
B. Bradyarrhythmias due to SA node inhibition
C. Increased heart rate and contractility with vasoconstriction
D. Stimulation of ciliated cell proliferation in the cardiac tissue
E. Blocking AV node conduction

9b.question: Which of the following statements about Chapman's reflex points is true?
options: A. They are found only in the anterior part of the body.
B. They have no diagnostic or therapeutic value.
C. They are palpable as gangliform contractions deep in the fascia.
D. They are treated by applying heat to the area.
E. They are directly related to somatic motor reflexes.

9b.question: Which of the following best describes a physiologic effect of the parasympathetic nervous system on the lower respiratory tract?
options: A. Goblet cell proliferation leads to thickening of secretions.
B. Bronchodilation with decreased secretory activity.
C. Bronchoconstriction and increased ciliated cell activity.
D. Increased smooth muscle relaxation.
E. Vasoconstriction and reduced lymphatic flow.

9b.question: Which of the following is true regarding the sympathetic effects on the gastrointestinal (GI) system?
options: A. Sympathetic stimulation decreases the risk of ulcers in critically ill patients.
B. Sympathetic activity promotes vasodilation and enhanced drug delivery.
C. Increased sympathetic tone can lead to sphincter constriction and gallstones.
D. Sympathetic stimulation leads to increased mucosal secretion.
E. Visceral afferents from above the pain line follow the parasympathetics.

9b.question: What is the role of primary afferent nociceptors (PANs) in reflex facilitation?
options: A. They only respond to mechanical stimulation.
B. They have no effect on the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
C. PANs can potentiate the dorsal horn response to nociception.
D. PANs are only involved in somatic reflexes.
E. PANs decrease the likelihood of neuron excitation.

9b.question: Which statement best describes the relationship between the parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) and visceral afferents?
options: A. Visceral afferents in the PNS are primarily nociceptive.
B. Parasympathetic visceral afferents mainly carry physiologic information.
C. The PNS has preganglionic cell bodies located in T1-L2.
D. Parasympathetic ganglia are located far from their target organs.
E. The PNS has no role in modulating cardiac function.

9b.question: Which of the following best describes the sympathetic innervation of the heart?
options: A. It originates from T5-T9 and is associated with the celiac plexus.
B. It originates from T1-T5/6 and synapses in the cervical and paravertebral ganglia.
C. The right sympathetic supply influences the AV node, causing bradyarrhythmias.
D. The left sympathetic supply primarily affects the SA node.
E. It is only responsible for decreasing heart rate.

9b.question: Which of the following best describes the parasympathetic innervation of the lower GI tract?
options: A. CN III, VII, IX, X up to the splenic flexure
B. S2-S4 to the remaining GI and pelvic viscera
C. T5-T9 via the celiac plexus
D. T10-T12 for the descending colon
E. CN IX for the entire GI tract

9b.question: Which of the following describes the sympathetic innervation to the kidneys?
options: A. T1-T4 via the cervical ganglia
B. T5-T9 via the celiac plexus
C. T10-T12 via the superior mesenteric plexus
D. T12-L2 via the inferior mesenteric plexus
E. T2-T7 via the paravertebral ganglia

9b.question: Which of the following best describes a physiologic effect of parasympathetic stimulation on the heart?
options: A. Increased heart rate and vasoconstriction
B. Increased contractility and output
C. Decreased heart rate and bradyarrhythmias due to SA node effects
D. Vasoconstriction leading to increased blood pressure
E. Enhanced AV node conduction

9b.question: Which statement about facilitation is true?
options: A. It only involves sensory afferents without affecting motor neurons.
B. It results in a decreased response to stimuli due to desensitization.
C. It maintains neurons in a subthreshold state, requiring less stimulation for response.
D. It has no impact on viscerosomatic reflexes.
E. It only occurs with chronic somatic dysfunction.

9b.question: What is the effect of sympathetic stimulation on the lower respiratory tract?
options: A. Bronchoconstriction and increased secretion production
B. Relaxation of smooth muscle and bronchiolar dilation
C. Increased ciliated cell activity
D. Decreased goblet cell proliferation
E. Enhanced lymphatic drainage

9b.question: Which of the following describes the function of primary afferent nociceptors (PANs)?
options: A. They only respond to physiologic stimuli.
B. They convey pain signals to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
C. They are primarily involved in modulating blood pressure.
D. They inhibit interneurons to decrease pain perception.
E. They play no role in reflex facilitation.

10a.question: A 67-year-old female presents with a chronic cough and rib dysfunction. On examination, TART changes are noted in the upper thoracic region. Which level is most likely associated with the sympathetic innervation of the lungs?
options: B. T1-T6
C. C1-C2
D. L1-L3

10a.question: A patient with pneumonia has restricted diaphragmatic motion. Which of the following consequences is most likely to occur due to this restriction?
options: A. Increased goblet cell production
B. Reduced venous and lymphatic return
C. Hyperactivity in bronchial dilation
D. Improved lung compliance

10a.question: A 60-year-old male with respiratory distress is noted to have somatic dysfunction at the OA/C2 level. Which autonomic response is most affected by this dysfunction?
options: A. Increased sympathetic output
B. Reduced parasympathetic influence
C. Enhanced diaphragm contraction
D. Improved thoracic lymphatic drainage

10a.question: During examination, a patient with pneumonia demonstrates muscle spasticity and impaired motion localized at T5-T6. What type of reflex is most likely involved here?
options: A. Somatosomatic reflex
B. Viscerosomatic reflex
C. Myotatic reflex
D. Chapman’s reflex

10a.question: Which of the following findings is most consistent with a diagnosis involving sympathetic hyperactivity in the lung tissues?
options: A. Reduced muscle tone at the thoracic inlet
B. Low reflex thresholds at T1-T6
C. Increased parasympathetic tone
D. Improved bronchial circulation and expansion

10b.question: A patient with spinal pain. During the assessment, it is noted that the patient has difficulty maintaining spinal neutrality. What is the initial step in Facilitated Positional Release (FPR) for this condition?
options: A. Apply torsion to the affected segment.
B. Position the spine in flexion.
C. Reduce the anterior-posterior spinal curves to achieve a neutral position.
D. Introduce rotation to the side of the dysfunction.

10b.question: A 45-year-old female is being treated for hypertonicity in her thoracic spine. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the decrease in muscle tension when using FPR?
options: A. Increased alpha motor neuron activity.
B. Compression leading to a "quieting" of gamma motor gain and reduced stretch stimuli.
C. Activation of muscle spindles resulting in enhanced reflex response.
D. Stretching the muscle to reset spindle afferent signaling.

10b.question: Which of the following is considered a relative contraindication for the use of Facilitated Positional Release?
options: A. Local fracture of the vertebrae.
B. Severe joint instability.
C. Moderate foraminal stenosis with exacerbation risk.
D. History of hip prosthesis in lumbar discogenic FPR.

10b.question: During FPR treatment of a patient with a posterior cervical issue, which facilitating force is most commonly applied to initiate the release?
options: A. Traction.
B. Lateral flexion.
C. Torsion.
D. Compression.

10b.question: A physician performing FPR on a patient notes that the somatic dysfunction is Type II. Which type of muscle is primarily involved, and how is it targeted in treatment?
options: A. Larger regional muscle groups; treated with flexion.
B. Intrinsic deep muscles; positioned for their specific somatic dysfunction.
C. Anterior superficial muscles; placed in extension.
D. Posterior muscles; treated with contralateral rotation.

11.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with symptoms of sinusitis, including congestion, headache, and facial pain. Which osteopathic technique would be most effective to enhance venous and lymphatic drainage in this patient?
options: A. Rib raising
B. Suboccipital release
C. Galbreath technique
D. Myofascial release of the thoracic inlet

11.question: During an evaluation of a 50-year-old patient with asthma, which finding would indicate the involvement of secondary muscles of respiration due to chronic breathing difficulties?
options: A. Barrel chest with prominent pectoral muscles
B. Limited diaphragmatic excursion on deep inspiration
C. Rigidity in the lower thoracic spine
D. Hypertrophy of the scalenes and sternocleidomastoid muscles

11.question: A patient with COPD shows increased dead space on imaging. What is the most likely physical finding associated with this condition?
options: A. Elevated first ribs
B. Decreased thoracic kyphosis
C. Inhalation dysfunction of lower ribs
D. Decreased compliance of the diaphragm

11.question: A 45-year-old patient with chronic asthma presents with complaints of episodic dyspnea and chest tightness. According to osteopathic principles, which treatment approach would be best to address this patient's autonomic imbalance?
options: A. CV4 hold to enhance CSF flow
B. Rib raising and upper thoracic inhibition
C. Effleurage of the intercostal muscles
D. Sinus drainage technique

11.question: A patient reports persistent difficulty breathing following a recent respiratory infection. Osteopathic examination reveals somatic dysfunctions of the upper thoracic region and cervical spine. Which of the following is most consistent with viscerosomatic reflex findings in this patient?
options: A. T2-T6 dysfunction and cervical muscle spasms
B. C1-C2 rotation with sacral tenderness
C. T10-T12 restriction with rib compression
D. Sacroiliac joint hypermobility

11.question: A 60-year-old female presents with chronic bronchitis and has been experiencing difficulty breathing. Which OMT technique would be most beneficial to assist with improving lymphatic drainage and reducing congestion?
options: A. Cervical stretching
B. Thoracic lymphatic pump
C. Suboccipital release
D. Rib raising

11.question: A patient is diagnosed with asthma and reports frequent nocturnal coughing. Which musculoskeletal finding is most commonly associated with this symptom?
options: A. Elevated diaphragm
B. Decreased rib motion in the lower ribs
C. Spasms of the sternocleidomastoid and scalenes
D. Rigidity of the lumbar spine

11.question: Which of the following would be an expected finding in a patient with emphysema?
options: A. Sunken chest and exhalation dysfunctions
B. Barrel chest with inhalation restrictions
C. Flattened diaphragm and pursed-lip breathing
D. Decreased lung compliance with increased inspiratory work

11.question: A 47-year-old patient presents with symptoms of sinusitis, including facial pain and congestion. Which Chapman’s point would be targeted for treatment to alleviate sinus issues?
options: A. Second intercostal space near the sternum
B. Superior aspect of the clavicle
C. Lateral edge of the scapula
D. Medial to the lesser trochanter

11.question: In patients with obstructive lung disease, what thoracic dysfunction is most commonly observed due to prolonged use of accessory muscles?
options: A. Locked-down lower ribs
B. Locked-up upper ribs
C. Decreased thoracic kyphosis
D. Flexion lesions in the lumbar spine

11.question: A 50-year-old female presents with complaints of dyspnea, persistent wheezing, and chest tightness. Which of the following findings would indicate sympathetic overactivity in this patient?
options: A. Increased production of ciliated columnar epithelial cells
B. Thick and tenacious mucus production
C. Decreased secretion of goblet cells
D. Increased diaphragmatic excursion during inhalation
E. Predominant use of parasympathetic innervation

11.question: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of chronic sinusitis reports worsening facial pressure and congestion. On examination, the physician notes decreased ciliary activity and swollen nasal turbinates. Which OMT approach would most effectively aid sinus drainage?
options: A. Rib raising technique
B. Cervical muscle energy treatment
C. Sinus drainage technique using effleurage
D. Myofascial release of the thoracic inlet
E. Diaphragmatic doming

11.question: A 70-year-old male patient with a long history of COPD presents with pursed-lip breathing and elevated first ribs. Which of the following best explains his breathing strategy?
options: A. To reduce the work of inspiration by lowering diaphragm pressure
B. To facilitate air trapping and maintain thoracic rigidity
C. To create positive airway pressure during exhalation
D. To increase ciliary clearance and remove mucus efficiently
E. To enhance diaphragmatic contraction for deeper breaths

11.question: A 55-year-old female with asthma reports experiencing difficulty breathing, especially during exhalation. Physical examination reveals rigidity in the thoracic spine. Which of the following muscle groups is likely involved in maintaining this rigidity?
options: A. Scalene and sternocleidomastoid muscles
B. Internal and external intercostal muscles
C. Rectus abdominus and oblique muscles
D. Pectoralis major and minor muscles
E. Trapezius and latissimus dorsi muscles

11.question: An 18-year-old male athlete presents for a pre-participation exam and mentions experiencing mild shortness of breath during vigorous training. He has a history of childhood asthma. What is the most appropriate OMT treatment to increase thoracic compliance and improve ventilation?
options: A. Suboccipital release to reset parasympathetics
B. Rib raising to reduce sympathetic tone
C. Thoracic pump to enhance lymphatic drainage
D. Effleurage over the chest to reduce congestion
E. Cervical stretching to increase lung compliance

12a.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with left-sided abdominal pain that radiates to the left groin. The pain began abruptly after intense physical activity. Physical examination reveals hypertonicity from T11 to L2 and mild fever. What is the most likely cause of his pain?
options: A. Kidney infection spreading to surrounding muscles.
B. Ureteric stone causing spasms and referred pain.
C. Left-sided SI joint dysfunction due to trauma.
D. Inflammation of the quadratus lumborum from muscle overuse.
E. Psoas syndrome contributing to iliolumbar ligament pain.

12a.question: A 50-year-old woman complains of chronic right flank pain that is exacerbated when she stands for long periods. She reports relief when lying down. Physical exam shows no signs of infection but a notable decrease in tissue mobility around the right kidney. What is the possible explanation for her symptoms?
options: A. Chronic nephrolithiasis.
B. Renal ptosis affecting the ureter.
C. Costovertebral dysfunction causing muscle strain.
D. Psoas syndrome leading to ureteral compression.
E. Generalized muscle fatigue and spasm.

12a.question: A patient reports dull, aching pain in the lower back that started after a significant loss of weight over a short period. He mentions that the pain worsens with standing and feels less severe when sitting. On examination, there is tenderness at the T12-L1 level and hypermobility of the lower ribs. What could be contributing to this pain?
options: A. Lumbar disc herniation.
B. Nephroptosis due to lack of supporting perirenal fat.
C. SI joint inflammation from poor posture.
D. Spinal stenosis at the lumbar level.
E. Chronic infection of the kidney.

12a.question: A 32-year-old runner complains of right-sided back pain radiating to the lower abdomen and anterior thigh. The pain began after a long-distance run and worsens with hip flexion. Palpation reveals tightness in the psoas muscle. Which of the following is the most plausible cause of the pain?
options: A. Psoas spasm resulting in ureteric irritation.
B. Sacroiliac joint dysfunction radiating to the anterior thigh.
C. Lumbar facet syndrome involving T11-L1.
D. Piriformis syndrome mimicking ureteral pain.
E. Chronic appendicitis radiating to the back.

12a.question: A 29-year-old athlete experiences sudden, sharp pain in the left lower back after a weightlifting session. The pain is accompanied by nausea and radiates to the left groin. Physical examination shows tenderness over T11-L2 and positive Lloyd’s sign. What is the most likely mechanism of this pain?
options: A. Acute disc herniation.
B. Renal colic due to left ureteral stone.
C. Iliopsoas strain from improper form.
D. Quadratus lumborum strain due to lifting.
E. Sacroiliac joint sprain.

12a.question: A 40-year-old patient presents with left-sided flank pain radiating to the lower abdomen, nausea, and hematuria. Physical examination shows hypertonicity from T11-L1 and costovertebral tenderness. What is the most likely mechanism of the pain?
options: A. Renal infection causing referred muscle pain.
B. Lumbar strain from lifting.
C. Ureteral stone with associated ureterospasm.
D. Quadratus lumborum strain from poor posture.
E. Psoas syndrome affecting the left flank.

12a.question: A 28-year-old woman reports right-sided flank pain that worsens when she moves or stands for long periods and improves when lying down. On examination, there is no sign of infection, but the kidney is palpable on deep inspiration. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
options: A. Right-sided kidney infection.
B. Ureteral stone in the lower ureter.
C. Nephroptosis due to a "dropped kidney."
D. Psoas muscle strain causing kidney displacement.
E. Herniated disc impinging on nerve roots.

12a.question: A 35-year-old runner presents with dull pain in the lower back that radiates to the anterior thigh and worsens with hip flexion. Physical examination reveals tightness in the psoas muscle and positive Thomas test. What is the most plausible cause of this pain?
options: A. Quadratus lumborum strain.
B. Psoas spasm creating ureteral compression.
C. Sacroiliac joint dysfunction.
D. Kidney infection affecting the lower back.
E. Ureteral stone in the middle ureter.

12a.question: A patient comes to the clinic with sudden, sharp pain in the left lower back that radiates to the groin, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Lloyd’s sign is positive, and examination shows tenderness along T12-L1. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
options: A. Acute disc herniation at L1-L2.
B. Renal colic due to left ureteral stone.
C. Psoas muscle strain with nerve impingement.
D. Left-sided quadratus lumborum spasm.
E. Lumbar sprain from heavy lifting.

12a.question: A 42-year-old man complains of lower abdominal pain and suprapubic discomfort that started after a period of dehydration. He reports pain radiating to the scrotum and frequent urination. Physical examination reveals hypertonicity at L1-L2. What could be causing these symptoms?
options: A. Inguinal hernia.
B. Lower ureteral stone causing referred pain.
C. Chronic prostatitis.
D. Psoas syndrome affecting the lower abdomen.
E. SI joint dysfunction causing abdominal pain.

12a.question: A 33-year-old patient presents with right-sided flank pain that radiates to the groin, along with nausea and intermittent chills. Physical examination reveals tenderness at the costovertebral angle and hypertonicity at T11-L2. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
options: A. Appendicitis
B. Right kidney infection
C. Ureteral stone in the upper ureter
D. Psoas muscle strain
E. Sacroiliac joint dysfunction

12a.question: A patient complains of left lower back pain that started after heavy lifting and radiates to the anterior thigh. The pain worsens with hip flexion and is accompanied by a positive Thomas test. What is the most likely underlying issue?
options: A. Quadratus lumborum spasm
B. Nephrolithiasis causing referred pain
C. Psoas syndrome with potential ureteral irritation
D. Disc herniation at L4-L5
E. Costovertebral joint dysfunction

12a.question: A 46-year-old man has persistent suprapubic pain that worsens with urination and radiates to the scrotum. He has experienced mild fever and reports being dehydrated recently. On physical examination, hypertonicity is noted at L1-L2. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
options: A. Urinary tract infection
B. Lower ureteral stone with referred pain
C. Psoas muscle strain
D. Inguinal hernia
E. Prostatitis

12a.question: A patient reports pain in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen that radiates to the groin and is associated with nausea and vomiting. Examination reveals tenderness at T11-L2 and a positive Lloyd’s sign. What is the most plausible diagnosis?
options: A. Diverticulitis
B. Renal colic due to a left ureteral stone
C. Iliopsoas muscle spasm
D. SI joint dysfunction
E. Chronic constipation

12a.question: A 25-year-old athlete presents with low back pain that radiates to the right anterior thigh after a soccer game. He also reports pain during hip flexion and tightness in the lower back. Physical exam shows boggy tissue texture changes at T11-L1. What could be the underlying issue?
options: A. Ureteral stone in the middle ureter
B. Psoas spasm causing referred pain
C. Quadratus lumborum strain
D. SI joint inflammation
E. Renal infection

12a.question: What organ does the kidney connect to by the hepatorenal ligament?
options: A. Spleen
B. Liver
C. Stomach
D. Pancreas
E. Jejunum

12a.question: Where would pain from the upper ureters typically refer to?
options: A. The groin area
B. The suprapubic region
C. The ASIS anteriorly to the border of rectus abdominis
D. The posterior iliac crest
E. Below the inguinal ligament

12a.question: Which spinal levels are associated with sympathetic innervation to the kidneys?
options: A. T5-T9
E. L1-L2

12a.question: What effect does increased sympathetic tone have on the kidneys?
options: A. Increases glomerular filtration rate
B. Reduces renal activity and decreases urine output
C. Enhances blood flow to the kidneys
D. Maintains ureter peristalsis
E. Decreases blood pressure

12a.question: A patient with nephroptosis might experience relief from symptoms by:
options: A. Performing deep inhalation exercises
B. Lying down
C. Increasing intraabdominal pressure
D. Drinking more fluids
E. Moving frequently

12b.question: A 42-year-old male presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and low back discomfort. The osteopathic structural exam reveals somatic dysfunctions at T12-L2 and bilateral sacral base restrictions. Which of the following treatments would be most effective in reducing sympathetic tone and improving his symptoms?
options: A. OMT to S2-S4
B. Sacral rocking
C. Treating the T12-L2 area
D. Thoracic inlet release
E. Ischiorectal fossa release

12b.question: A 33-year-old postpartum female reports stress urinary incontinence when coughing and sneezing. She has no signs of infection and a normal pelvic exam. Osteopathic findings show pubic symphysis dysfunction and increased lumbar lordosis. What treatment would best address the incontinence?
options: A. Anti-cholinergic medication
B. Kegel exercises
C. Treatment of the pubic symphysis
D. Sacral counterstrain
E. OMT to T12-L2

12b.question: A 50-year-old man complains of burning pain during urination and perineal discomfort. Exam reveals a positive Lloyd’s punch test and tissue texture changes from T10-L2. Which osteopathic treatment approach would best assist with lymphatic drainage and symptom relief?
options: A. Sacral rocking
B. Rib raising to T12-L2
C. Pelvic diaphragm release
D. OMT to the ischiorectal fossa
E. OA decompression

12b.question: A 29-year-old female has frequent UTIs and reports pelvic floor pain. Osteopathic findings indicate pelvic diaphragm tension and bilateral thoracolumbar dysfunction. What is the main goal of osteopathic treatment in this patient?
options: A. Increase pelvic floor tension
B. Normalize sympathetic tone and promote lymphatic drainage
C. Decrease urinary pH
D. Strengthen the psoas muscle
E. Address cervical spine alignment

12b.question: A 46-year-old male presents with slow urinary stream and lower abdominal pain. Physical and structural exams reveal a restricted sacral base and somatic dysfunction at T11-L2. Which treatment would best address the patient's urinary flow issues?
options: A. Treating the posterior Chapman’s point at L1
B. Sacral counterstrain
C. OMT to T11-L2
D. Kegel exercises
E. Thoracic cage mobilization

12b.question: A 42-year-old male presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and low back discomfort. The osteopathic structural exam reveals somatic dysfunctions at T12-L2 and bilateral sacral base restrictions. Which of the following treatments would be most effective in reducing sympathetic tone and improving his symptoms?
options: A. OMT to S2-S4
B. Sacral rocking
C. Treating the T12-L2 area
D. Thoracic inlet release
E. Ischiorectal fossa release

12b.question: A 33-year-old postpartum female reports stress urinary incontinence when coughing and sneezing. She has no signs of infection and a normal pelvic exam. Osteopathic findings show pubic symphysis dysfunction and increased lumbar lordosis. What treatment would best address the incontinence?
options: A. Anti-cholinergic medication
B. Kegel exercises
C. Treatment of the pubic symphysis
D. Sacral counterstrain
E. OMT to T12-L2

12b.question: A 50-year-old man complains of burning pain during urination and perineal discomfort. Exam reveals a positive Lloyd’s punch test and tissue texture changes from T10-L2. Which osteopathic treatment approach would best assist with lymphatic drainage and symptom relief?
options: A. Sacral rocking
B. Rib raising to T12-L2
C. Pelvic diaphragm release
D. OMT to the ischiorectal fossa
E. OA decompression

12b.question: A 29-year-old female has frequent UTIs and reports pelvic floor pain. Osteopathic findings indicate pelvic diaphragm tension and bilateral thoracolumbar dysfunction. What is the main goal of osteopathic treatment in this patient?
options: A. Increase pelvic floor tension
B. Normalize sympathetic tone and promote lymphatic drainage
C. Decrease urinary pH
D. Strengthen the psoas muscle
E. Address cervical spine alignment

options: A. Treating the posterior Chapman’s point at L1

12b.question: A 31-year-old female presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain. She denies fever or chills. The osteopathic structural exam reveals increased lumbar lordosis and pubic symphysis dysfunction. Which treatment would best support urinary function and reduce symptoms?
options: A. OMT to T5-T9
B. Sacral counterstrain
C. Pelvic diaphragm release
D. Rib raising to T10-L2
E. OMT to the ischiorectal fossa

12b.question: A 55-year-old male reports perineal pain, burning during urination, and lower back discomfort. Structural findings show a positive Lloyd’s punch test and sacral base posterior dysfunction. Which osteopathic treatment is most appropriate to address autonomic imbalance and pain?
options: A. Thoracic inlet release
B. Treating the T12-L2 area
C. OA decompression
D. OMT to the sacrum and S2-4
E. Posterior Chapman’s point therapy at S1

12b.question: A 28-year-old female presents with pain during urination and pelvic floor discomfort. The osteopathic exam reveals tension in the pelvic diaphragm and paraspinal tissue texture changes from T10-L2. Which treatment would best facilitate drainage and promote healing?
options: A. OMT to the pubic bones
B. Kegel exercises
C. Treating the ischiorectal fossa
D. Rib raising to T12-L2
E. Anterior Chapman’s point pressure therapy

12b.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents with sacral base dysfunction and paraspinal muscle tension at T10-L2. What is the main goal of osteopathic treatment for this patient?
options: A. Strengthen pelvic floor muscles
B. Balance sympathetic and parasympathetic tone and promote lymphatic flow
C. Increase muscle tone in the psoas
D. Decrease bladder wall tone
E. Address Chapman’s reflexes

12b.question: A 34-year-old female complains of stress urinary incontinence after her third delivery. The osteopathic exam shows increased lumbar lordosis and pelvic diaphragm weakness. Which intervention is most suitable to improve her symptoms?
options: A. OMT to the sacroiliac joints
B. Rib raising to T5-T9
C. Kegel exercises
D. Ischiorectal fossa release
E. Sacral rocking

options: A. Treating the posterior Chapman’s point at L1
B. Sacral counterstrain
C. OMT to T11-L2

options: A. Anti-cholinergic medication
B. Kegel exercises

options: A. Sacral rocking
B. Rib raising to T12-L2
C. Pelvic diaphragm release

12b.question: A 29-year-old female has frequent UTIs and reports pelvic floor pain. Osteopathic findings indicate pelvic diaphragm tension and bilateral thoracolumbar dysfunction. What is the main goal of osteopathic treatment in this patient?
options: A. Increase pelvic floor tension
B. Normalize sympathetic tone and promote lymphatic drainage
C. Decrease urinary pH
D. Strengthen the psoas muscle
E. Address cervical spine alignment

12b.question: A 30-year-old female reports lower abdominal pain, increased urinary frequency, and burning during urination. Physical exam reveals positive Lloyd’s punch test and tenderness over the suprapubic area. Which treatment approach is most effective for normalizing sympathetic tone?
options: A. OMT to T5-T9
B. Sacral counterstrain
C. OMT to T10-L2
D. Treating the OA joint
E. Pelvic diaphragm release

12b.question: A 47-year-old male presents with chronic pelvic pain, perineal discomfort, and a history of non-bacterial prostatitis. Examination shows paraspinal tension at T12-L2 and restricted sacral motion. What is the primary goal of osteopathic treatment for this patient?
options: A. Increase sympathetic tone
B. Promote lymphatic drainage and reduce pelvic floor tension
C. Strengthen the pubic symphysis
D. Enhance bladder wall contraction
E. Reduce urinary pH

12b.question: A 26-year-old postpartum patient experiences urinary leakage when laughing and reports pelvic heaviness. Structural findings include lumbar lordosis and weakened pelvic floor muscles. Which treatment would best help reduce her incontinence?
options: A. Rib raising to T12-L2
B. OMT to S2-S4
C. Kegel exercises
D. Sacral mobilization
E. Ischiorectal fossa release

12b.question: A 52-year-old male with a history of kidney stones presents with severe flank pain radiating to the groin. The patient has no fever but reports hematuria. What osteopathic treatment would support lymphatic drainage and pain relief in this patient?
options: A. OMT to the cervical spine
B. Pelvic diaphragm release
C. Sacral rocking
D. Treating the thoracic inlet
E. OMT to T5-T9

12b.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with urinary urgency, pelvic pain, and no signs of infection. Exam findings show tension in the pelvic diaphragm and tissue texture changes at S2-S4. Which osteopathic approach would most likely address her symptoms?
options: A. OMT to the thoracolumbar junction
B. Sacral base counterstrain
C. Treating the ischiorectal fossa
D. Pelvic floor strengthening exercises
E. Rib raising to T5-T9

13a.question: A 50-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents with sharp epigastric pain radiating to the chest. An osteopathic exam shows T5-9 warm, boggy paraspinal muscles on the left. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute myocardial infarction
B. GERD
C. Perforated viscus
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Costochondritis

13a.question: A 63-year-old female presents with tearing pain that radiates from her chest to her upper back. Physical examination reveals hypertonic paravertebral muscles at T1-5. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Gallbladder colic
B. Gastroesophageal reflux
C. Aortic dissection
D. Anxiety
E. Intercostal neuralgia

13a.question: A 47-year-old male with a history of anxiety presents with episodes of chest tightness and palpitations. Osteopathic structural examination shows hypertonic upper thoracic paraspinal muscles. What is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
options: A. Aortic aneurysm
B. Acute pericarditis
C. Anxiety-induced hypersympathotonia
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Gastroesophageal reflux

13a.question: A 45-year-old female presents with sharp, right upper quadrant pain radiating to her shoulder. Osteopathic examination shows T5-9 warm and boggy paraspinal muscles on the right. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Proton-pump inhibitor
B. Cardiac enzymes and EKG
C. Cholecystectomy consultation
D. Indirect treatment of the left thoracic inlet
E. Muscle energy to treat C2

13a.question: A 28-year-old male presents with left-sided chest pain after a viral illness. He points with one finger to an area of tenderness near his sternum. Osteopathic examination shows tender points along the 3rd to 5th costal cartilages on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Costochondritis
B. Tietze’s syndrome
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Gastroesophageal reflux
E. Pulmonary embolism

13a.question: A 49-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with vague chest discomfort described as a deep, dull ache. Physical examination reveals hypertonic paravertebral muscles at T1-4 on the left. Which of the following is the most likely organ involved?
options: A. Gallbladder
B. Stomach
C. Heart
D. Esophagus
E. Lungs

13a.question: A 60-year-old female reports episodes of burning chest pain that radiates from her epigastrum to the neck, especially after meals. An osteopathic exam shows T5-9 warm and boggy paraspinal muscles on the left. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
options: A. Aortic dissection
B. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
C. Acute myocardial infarction
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Costochondritis

13a.question: A 35-year-old male presents with sharp, right-sided anterior chest pain exacerbated by deep breathing and coughing. Osteopathic structural examination reveals rib 6-8 exhalation dysfunction on the right. Which treatment would be most appropriate for this patient?
options: A. Rib raising at T1-4
B. Indirect treatment of the left thoracic inlet
C. Muscle energy for rib 6-8
D. OA decompression
E. Rib raising at T5-9 on the left

13a.question: A patient with a history of gallbladder colic presents to the emergency department with right-sided pain radiating to the back. Physical exam shows warm paraspinal muscles at T5-9 on the right. What is the primary segmental level involved?
options: E. C1-C4

13a.question: A 55-year-old female with anxiety presents with chest pain. Physical examination reveals a stooped posture and hypertonic pectoralis minor. Which of the following is the most likely non-cardiac diagnosis?
options: A. Aortic aneurysm
B. Costochondritis
C. Tietze’s syndrome
D. Intercostal neuralgia
E. Pulmonary embolism

13a.question: A 58-year-old male presents to the clinic with vague, non-radiating chest discomfort that worsens with exertion. Osteopathic exam reveals paraspinal hypertonicity and bogginess at T1-5 on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
options: A. Proton-pump inhibitor trial
B. EKG and cardiac enzymes
C. Muscle energy to treat T1-5
D. Referral for gastrointestinal evaluation
E. Indirect treatment of the thoracic inlet

13a.question: A 40-year-old female reports right-sided chest pain that she can pinpoint with her finger, and it is exacerbated by deep breathing. The osteopathic structural exam finds tender points on the right 3rd to 5th costal cartilages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute pericarditis
B. Costochondritis
C. GERD
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Tietze’s syndrome

13a.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic lung disease presents with left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals a decreased breath sound on the left side. Which osteopathic treatment would most benefit this patient’s condition?
options: A. Rib raising for ribs 1-4
B. Muscle energy for T1-4
C. Diaphragmatic release
D. OA decompression
E. Rib raising for ribs 6-10

13a.question: A 51-year-old female presents with intermittent midline chest pain and a vague burning sensation after meals. Osteopathic findings include T5-9 paraspinal muscle spasm on the left. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
options: A. Aortic dissection
B. Acute myocardial infarction
C. GERD
D. Anxiety
E. Gallbladder colic

13a.question: A 30-year-old male who recently recovered from a viral infection complains of sharp left-sided chest pain that worsens with coughing. He points to the pain near his sternum, and the osteopathic exam reveals tender points at ribs 2-4 on the left. Which of the following somatic dysfunctions is most consistent with this presentation?
options: A. Rib 1 inhalation dysfunction on the right
B. Rib 6-8 exhalation dysfunction on the left
C. Rib 2-4 exhalation dysfunction on the left
D. Rib 4-6 inhalation dysfunction on the right
E. Flattened thoracic diaphragm
